bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to William Crawford Gorgas, November 6, 1917

div1.p: Kean provides a detailed description of Ambulance Corps problems; including supply, accommodation, and pay difficulties.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to William Crawford Gorgas, November 6, 1917
div1.p:
Your letter of September 14 is just received, and it gives me great pleasure
to feel that I am in letter communication with you, although I hope that future
correspondence will not be subject to such enormous delays. Your letter took a
month longer to come than Captain Doyle's, which was written October 13 and ar-
rived today.

You understand by this time, I am sure, because it has been explained both
in my letters and in cable, that the hitch about sending over all the Allentown
sections is due to the fact that the ambulance service at the Front is under
the Ministry of Armament and Munitions, which does not seem to desire us to take
over the entire ambulance service of the French army as was proposed by Marshal
Joffre. My liaison officer, Captain Aujay, told me this morning that the Service
Automobile Militaire desired us to furnish them 63 sections. Two sections will
also be needed for the military service of Paris, and about 10 to be held at the
Base Camp for emergencies and to furnish details for the army parks and reserve
parks and the depot of spare parts. This will make the total needs of the service
here, as at present constituted, 75 sections. We have now in service at the front
as follows:

When the 10 sections whose arrival I am expecting daily and with impatience
come, I will still be 17 sections short of this program, and I will ask General
Pershing to cable for them as soon as satisfactory arrangements can be made for
caring for them during the winter. I am by no means anxious to see men sent over
here to sleep in the mud in this cold and harsh climate, as I believe they will be
much better off in the United States until we can make arrangements to take care
of them.

The Italian service may make very considerable additional demands on our
service, as I have an intimation already that the French would like to send some
of our sections to Italy. The question as to whether this should be done, in view
of the fact that we are not at war with Austria, has been unofficially brought up,
but I see no validity to that objection, because ambulance sections being a part
of the sanitary service it is not an act of hostility or in any way contrary to
the letter or spirit of the Hague treaty to send them to any belligerent. The
question has not yet, however, been put up to General Pershing, and I do not
know what view he will take of it.

There has been some talk in the Army about the great number of Ford ambu-
lances lying crated on the pier at St. Nazaire, but to all critics I have replied
that all of these Fords would have been in use if we had been allowed to bring
2
over our sections as well as our cars. The fact is, however, that these cars
have been the salvation of the Army, because the Quartermaster Department has
been very short of transportation, and the Medical Department, which is de-
pendent on them, equally short. Therefore I have turned over 200 cars to the
Medical Department, 200 to the Quartermaster Department, and 70 to the Signal
Corps, with the understanding that they would be replaced by them later. This
replacement will, I think, have to be by a transfer of funds on the books of
the Treasury and a fresh order of cars from Ford. I have been very much averse
to having these cars assembled to stand out in the weather and deteriorate, es-
pecially as in this way we spoil tires, of which article we are very short.
The French automobile service have been promising me storage for two months
but without any tangible results. So, I have turned to the Service de Sante,
who have placed at my disposal, in the last day or two, a splendid great store-
house just south of Paris, at the Fort de Vanves, where I can store out auto-
biles crated, and have a depot of spare parts.

The spare part question is at present very urgent, as requisitions for
spare parts come in every day.

I think that we will soon transfer our Base Camp to Ft. de Vanves, from
Sandricourt, which is 40 kilometres north of Paris. This will make our admin-
istration much more handy and efficient. I think the automobile service is a
little jealous at my accepting anything at the hands of the Service de Sante,
as there is a good deal of jealousy between them; but my reply to all remarks
is that promises will not shelter either men or supplies, and so I had to turn
to whoever would help me out.

It has been so far impossible to get any clothing, and my men are getting
in a very bad way for lack of it; but I understand the same lack exists in the
United States. I hope it will be relieved by a shipment before long.

You will be pleased to know that the Allentown sections at the front are
doing well, and I have heard of one citation already, and many complimentary
reports of the efficiency and gallantry of several of them during the recent
battle at Chemin des Dames.

I have been very much handicapped by my inability to get a suitable office,
but the Quartermaster's Office has at last rented me a stable which has very
good rooms over it and will make a very satisfactory office. I expect to be
able to get some quarters for my men in connection with it and start a mess,
so that they can live comfortably and decently. The conditions of living for
enlisted men in Paris are very hard, as all commutation was cut off on the
1st of the month, and the two enlisted men's messes are said to be exceedingly
poor, besides being so distant from my office that if the men had to eat there
they would spend their entire time traveling back and forth and would have no
time to give to the work of the office.

I am just transferring the offices from the old American Field Service
office into my office and making a consolidation of the two. Major Andrew will
have charge of motor transportation and will, I hope, be very useful at the head
of that very important branch.

We have had much difficulty in getting to the sections their pay and their
commutation of rations. The latter has given especial difficulty as the French
3
are acoustomed to having commutation paid in advance and do business on a cash
basis, whereas, you know, it is one of the peculiarities of our regulations
that a man has to eat his meals before he can pay for them, and if he cannot get
credit he will starve.

Birmingham has come back today from our Headquarters, having completed his
inspection of the British and French, as well as the American, fronts. He is
looking very well and is in fine spirits and will bring back a great deal of ex-
ceedingly valuable information for the Office.

If I could only hear tomorrow that the 10 sections and 300 unassigned men
from Allentown had arrived, I would be perfectly happy and would feel that the
future is all smooth sailing and that my chief difficulties are behind me.

Please turn this letter over to Major Wrightson after you have read it.
My next letter will be written to him direct.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, Kean jrk-oh
Major General W. C. Gorgas, USA
Surgeon General
Washington, D. C.
